newsitem.title: USA: U.S. corp mart abuzz about bank trust pfd floaters.
newsitem.headline: U.S. corp mart abuzz about bank trust pfd floaters.

text.p: Floating-rate trust preferred stock is the latest hot product in the U.S. investment-grade corporate bond market, according to market sources who expect a pickup in issuance of these securities this week.

NationsBank Corp is expected to hit the market on Tuesday with a global offering of $500 million of floating-rate "capital securities," the bank's proprietary name for trust preferred stock. NationsBanc Capital Markets and Lehman Brothers Inc will jointly manage the offering .
Market players note most trust preferred stock has been issued with fixed-rate coupons to date.
Issuing floating rate securities allows issuers to tap a different investor base which is not as saturated with trust preferred stock, syndicate sources say.
And banks, who are expected to issue much of the product, favor floating rate borrowing as many of their assets are floating rate as well.
Market sources say the NationsBank securities will have coupons indexed to three-month Libor. They will have 30-year maturities, which will not be callable for 10 years.
Trust preferred securities are treated as bonds by most investors and rating agencies.
Price talk on the NationsBank deal was unavailable.
Bear Stearns & Co Inc is also expected to issue $150 million in 30-year trust preferred securities which will have a hybrid fixed/floating rate structure sometime this week.
Analysts say banks and other financial institutions are likely to resume issuing trust preferred securities in force after a brief hiatus.

"Banks are typically blacked out from issuing during their earnings reporting period. Now that most have reported for the fourth quarter, expect them to come back to the market," a bond syndicate source said.
Elsewhere in the trust preferred primary market, Arvin Industries Inc is expected to issue a $100 million 30-year trust preferred deal via Merrill Lynch & Co later this week.
In the junk bond primary market, the pace of new issuance is expected to kick into overdrive with at least six new deals scheduled to price this week, syndicate sources said.

"Flows into high-yield funds were over $350 million (last week), continuing to fuel a healthy high-yield market," stated Frank Benevento, head of junk bond capital markets at CIBC Wood Gundy Securities Corp.
New high-yield issues expected to price this week include:
-Multicanal S.A.'s 144a offering of $125 million in notes due 2002 and $125 million in notes due 2007 via Credit Suisse First Boston
-Orion Network Systems' $100 million zero coupon bond deal via Morgan Stanley & Co Inc.
-Petro Stopping Centers' 144a offering of $125 million in senior notes due 2007 via CIBC Woody Gundy.
-Electronic Retailing Systems International's 144a offering of $100 million of senior discount notes due 2004 via Credit Suisse.
Also on the plate for this week are two PIK preferred stock deals, exchangeable for junk bonds. They are:
-Nextlink Communications' $125 million senior redeemable exchangeable PIK preferred stock 144a offering via Merrill Lynch.
-Pegasus Communications Corp's $100 million cumulative exchangeable preferred stock 144a offering via CIBC Wood Gundy.
